content.raw:
Thanks to a discussion with @jordanlack, I think I understand the issues a little better. I think there should be a field `orientation_initialization` element with a string describing how the initial IMU orientation is determined (names open to suggestion):

* `identity`: (current behavior) the initial IMU output is always an identity quaternion, and subsequent orientation measurements are relative to the initial sensor pose
* `accelerometer`: the IMU uses the 3-axis accelerometer measurement to identify the gravity vector direction. This can be converted to a quaternion using an [axis-angle relationship](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/fb2cf09270c1425e137080b736fa852a12298cf9/include/ignition/math/Quaternion.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Quaternion.hh-243). The yaw angle is somewhat arbitrary.
* `NED` / `NWU` / `ENU`: the accelerometer and a compass are used to identify the true orientation of the IMU in a global frame. The name here should correspond to a known global frame. We will probably want to use the `spherical_coordinates` data for computing this.

Thanks to a discussion with @jordanlack, I think I understand the issues a little better. I think there should be a field orientation_initialization element with a string describing how the initial IMU orientation is determined (names open to suggestion):

  • identity: (current behavior) the initial IMU output is always an identity quaternion, and subsequent orientation measurements are relative to the initial sensor pose
  • accelerometer: the IMU uses the 3-axis accelerometer measurement to identify the gravity vector direction. This can be converted to a quaternion using an axis-angle relationship. The yaw angle is somewhat arbitrary.
  • NED / NWU / ENU: the accelerometer and a compass are used to identify the true orientation of the IMU in a global frame. The name here should correspond to a known global frame. We will probably want to use the spherical_coordinates data for computing this.
